In some cases when working with a sum in sigma notation, we may wish to rewrite the sum so that its index begins at a particular value – typically 𝑖 = 0 or 𝑖 = 1. This process is known as reindexing the sum. There are multiple methods to reindex a sum, which we will explore by rewriting the sum 4∑︁ 𝑖=2 1 2𝑖 + 1 = 1 5 + 1 7 + 1 9 to begin at 𝑖 = 0. Specifically, this new sum includes two extra terms: 1 (coming from 𝑖 = 0) and 1 3 (coming from 𝑖 = 1). For instance, 2 𝑥2 −16𝑥 + 33 can be written as 2(𝑥 −4)2 + 1. These two expressions are equivalent, but the latter is sometimes easier to work with. Let us refresh your memory of the completing the square process via an example. Consider the quadratic polynomial 𝑥2 + 6𝑥 + 5. To complete the square, we begin by adding and subtracting certain constant (represented below by a blank box) that will make part of the quadratic recognizable as a perfect square; hence the name “completing the square”! (︀ 𝑥2 + 6𝑥 + )︀ + 5 − . The constant that we introduce is obtained by dividing the coefficient of the 𝑥-term by 2 and then squaring the result. In our example, that coefficient is 6. We divide 6 by 2 to get 3, which we then square to obtain 9. Replacing the blank box above with 9, we obtain (𝑥2 + 6𝑥 + 9) −4. The bracketed term can now be factored as a perfect square. Indeed, we have 𝑥2 + 6𝑥 + 5 = (𝑥2 + 6𝑥 + 9) −4 = (𝑥 + 3)2 −4. Note that the 3 in the completed square can be obtained by dividing 6 (i.e., the coefficient of 𝑥) by 2. We divide this value by 2 and square the result to get 1, which is what we add to and subtract from the quadratic. We obtain 𝑥2 −2𝑥 + 9 = (𝑥2 −2𝑥 + 1) + 9−1 = (𝑥 −1)2 + 8. When working with a quadratic of the form 𝑎𝑥2 +𝑏𝑥+𝑐 where 𝑎 ̸= 1, there is one additional step that must be carried out when completing the square. Specifically, we must first factor 𝑎 from all of the terms involving 𝑥 before proceeding with our usual process. For example, consider the quadratic polynomial 2𝑥2 −16𝑥 + 33. Factoring the coefficient of 𝑎 = 2 from all of the terms involving 𝑥, we obtain 2(𝑥2 −8𝑥) + 33. Within the brackets, the coefficient of 𝑥 is −8. We divide this value by 2 and square the result to get 16, which we then add within the brackets to create a perfect square. Chapter 1 Integration In your first course in calculus, you studied the derivative of a function 𝑓. You were likely motivated by the problem of calculating the slope of a tangent line, but quickly learned that derivatives can be used for much more, such as approximating roots of functions, curve sketching, and optimization. In this chapter, we will explore the other side of the calculus coin: integral calculus! Our motivation will be to compute the area between the graph of a function and the 𝑥-axis over an interval [𝑎, 𝑏], which will lead us to the definition of the definite integral. Integrals, however, are useful for much more than just area calculations. They can be used to calculate volumes of 3D solids; the work done in applying force to an object over some distance; probabilities and expected values; forces and stresses on structures; fluid flow and heat transfer; and much more. Integrals are pivotal to the fields of Mathematics, Science, and Engineering. While integrals and derivatives may seems like completely separate concepts with unrelated motivations, these two branches of calculus turn out to be intimately linked. The connection is made precise in a result known as the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, which we will explore in the sections to come. By the end of this chapter, you will be able to • state the definition of the definite integral and evaluate simple integrals by definition; • state and apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to evaluate definite integrals; • recognize when and how to employ various integration techniques; • apply the tools of integral calculus to calculate areas and volumes. 1.1 The Definite Integral 1.1.1 Area Under a Curve In this section we will motivate the study of integral calculus through the problem of finding the area under the graph of a function. 12 Section 1.1 The Definite Integral 13 Given a continuous function 𝑓 that is non-negative on [ 𝑎, 𝑏] (that is, 𝑓(𝑥) ≥ 0 for all 𝑥 ∈[𝑎, 𝑏]), consider the region 𝑆 that lies under the graph of the function, above the 𝑥-axis, and between the vertical lines 𝑥 = 𝑎 and 𝑥 = 𝑏. 𝑎 𝑏 𝑆 𝑓(𝑥) 𝑥 𝑦 If the function 𝑓 is simple enough, we can use known geometric formulas to calculate the area of 𝑆. (b) Prove that 4 ≤ ∫︁ 4 0 √𝑥 𝑑𝑥≤6. 40 Chapter 1 Integration 1.3 Average Value of a Function A simple but important application of the definite integral is in defining the notion of an “average” of all values attained by a continuous function 𝑦 = 𝑓(𝑥) throughout an interval [𝑎, 𝑏]. The tools we develop here will play an important role in proving a major result in the next section: the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus! Let us first recall the usual process for averaging finitely many real numbers. Specifically, the average of numbers 𝑦1, 𝑦2, . . . , 𝑦𝑛 is calculated by adding all the 𝑦𝑖’s and dividing by 𝑛, the number of terms summed. That is, 𝑦avg = 𝑦1 + 𝑦2 + ··· + 𝑦𝑛 𝑛 . Suppose now we wish to calculate the average of all 𝑦-values attained by a continuous function 𝑦 = 𝑓(𝑥) for all 𝑥 ∈[𝑎, 𝑏]. Section 1.5 Fundamental Theorem of Calculus - Part II 53 1.5 Fundamental Theorem of Calculus - Part II Part I of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus shows that differentiation and integra- tion are inverse operations of one another. In this section we will explore the notion of an antiderivative, which—as the name suggests—is also related to the idea of “undoing” differentiation. Our discussion will culminate in Part II of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, an invaluable tool for evaluating definite integrals. Definition 1.5.1 Antiderivative Given a function 𝑓, an antiderivative of 𝑓 is a function 𝐹 such that 𝐹′= 𝑓. Example 1.5.2 Consider 𝑓(𝑥) = 𝑥3. The function 𝐹(𝑥) = 𝑥4 4 is an antiderivative of 𝑓, since 𝐹′(𝑥) = 𝑥3 = 𝑓(𝑥). Note, however, that this antiderivative is not unique. Indeed, 𝐺(𝑥) = 𝑥4 4 + 1 is also an antiderivative of 𝑓 since 𝐺′(𝑥) = 𝑥3 = 𝑓(𝑥) too. In fact, any function of the form 𝑥4 4 + 𝐶, 𝐶 ∈R will be an antiderivative of 𝑓, since the constant 𝐶 disappears when differentiated! As observed in the example above, if 𝐹 is an antiderivative of a function 𝑓, then so too is 𝐹(𝑥) + 𝐶 for any 𝐶 ∈R. In fact, adding a constant to 𝐹 turns out to be the only way to generate new antiderivatives for 𝑓. You may remember this result from Section 4.4 of the MATH 137 course notes, though it is also included below for completeness. Its proof is an application of the Mean Value Theorem. REMARK It may be somewhat unclear as to why we have chosen the term “indefinite integral” to represent the family of antiderivatives of a function 𝑓. It turns out, however, that there are good reasons for this. Recall from Part I of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus that if 𝑓 is continuous on [𝑎, 𝑏], then 𝑑 𝑑𝑥 ∫︁ 𝑥 𝑎 𝑓(𝑡) 𝑑𝑡 = 𝑓(𝑥). The connections between integrals and antiderivatives will be soon be further explored in Part II of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. It is known as the substitution rule or change of variables . 1.6.1 The Substitution Rule for Indefinite Integrals To motivate the technique, consider the calculation of the derivative of ( 𝑥2 + 1)7 via the chain rule: [︀ (𝑥2 + 1)7]︀′ = 7(𝑥2 + 1)6 ·(𝑥2 + 1)′ = 7(𝑥2 + 1)6 ·2𝑥 = 14𝑥(𝑥2 + 1)6. Since (𝑥2 + 1)7 is therefore an antiderivative of 14 𝑥(𝑥2 + 1)6, it follows that ∫︁ 14𝑥(𝑥2 + 1)6 𝑑𝑥 = (︀ 𝑥2 + 1 )︀7 + 𝐶. We have just evaluated the indefinite integral of 14𝑥(𝑥2 +1)6, a fairly complicated function. This is great, but it may feel a bit unsatisfying since we started the calculation with the antiderivative (𝑥2+1)7. The substitution rule gives us a way to evaluate the integral without knowing the answer up front. Before formally stating the substitution rule, let’s explore how it can be used in this example. To evaluate ∫︀ 14𝑥(𝑥2 + 1)6 𝑑𝑥, we will replace 𝑥2 + 1 with a new variable which we will call 𝑢. The differential 𝑑𝑥 can also be expressed in terms of 𝑢 by differentiating 𝑢 = 𝑥2 + 1 with respect to 𝑥: 𝑢 = 𝑥2 + 1 = ⇒ 𝑑𝑢 𝑑𝑥 = 2𝑥 =⇒ 𝑑𝑥 = 𝑑𝑢 2𝑥. Replacing 𝑥2 + 1 with 𝑢 and 𝑑𝑥 with 𝑑𝑢 2𝑥 , we obtain a new integral that is easier to evaluate: ∫︁ 14𝑥(𝑥2 + 1)6 𝑑𝑥 = ∫︁ 14𝑥 ·𝑢6 ·𝑑𝑢 2𝑥 = ∫︁ 7𝑢6 𝑑𝑢 = 𝑢7 + 𝐶. Finally, since 𝑢 = 𝑥2 + 1, we can express our answer in terms of the original variable, 𝑥. This technique – which is a variation on the substitution method from the previous section – involves replacing 𝑥 with a trigonometric function and using trigonometric identities to simplify the integral. In our example, it will be useful to let 𝑥 = sin 𝜃, hence 𝑑𝑥 = cos 𝜃 𝑑𝜃. By restricting 𝜃 to the interval −𝜋 2 ≤𝜃 ≤𝜋 2 and recognizing that sin 𝜃 is invertible on this domain, making the substitution 𝑥 = sin 𝜃 is equivalent to writing 𝜃 = arcsin 𝑥. REMARK In the previous section, all of the substitutions were of the form 𝑢 = 𝑔(𝑥), with the new variable, 𝑢, being expressed as a function of the original variable, 𝑥. REMARK There is an alternate approach one could use to determine the unknown coefficients 𝐴, 𝐵, 𝐶, and so on. To see how this approach works, consider once again the function 3𝑥+1 𝑥2+2𝑥−3 in Example 1.9.2. If we choose our 𝑥-values carefully, we can minimize the computations. Notice that 𝐵 will be eliminated from ( *) when we substitute 𝑥 = 1, leaving us with 3(1) + 1 = 𝐴(1 + 3) +𝐵(1 −1) = ⇒ 4 = 4𝐴 =⇒ 𝐴 = 1. Section 1.12 Volumes of Solids of Revolution 123 1.12 Volumes of Solids of Revolution In this section, we will modify our approach for calculating the area under a curve to deter- mine the volume of certain three-dimensional solids. We will focus on computing volumes of solids of revolution, solids obtained by revolving a two-dimensional region about an axis. Computing volumes of more general solids typically requires methods from multivariable calculus, which is beyond the scope of our study. We will explore two methods for calculating volumes of solids of revolution: one in which we “slice” the solid into disks or washers and another in which we decompose the solid into cylindrical shells. 1.12.1 Volumes by Disks and Washers Consider a region 𝑅 that lies below the graph of a continuous function 𝑓, above the 𝑥-axis, and between the vertical lines 𝑥 = 𝑎 and 𝑥 = 𝑏. If this region is revolved about the 𝑥-axis in three-dimensional space, a solid figure is produced. A solid formed in this way is called a solid of revolution . 124 Chapter 1 Integration To determine the volume of this solid, 𝑉 , let us think back to how we tackled a similar problem: finding the area under a curve. Our solution to the area problem was to divide the 𝑥-axis into small subintervals of width ∆ 𝑥 and approximate the area on each subinterval using the area of a rectangle. To adapt this approach to calculate the volume of our solid of revolution, let’s again start with a partition of the interval [𝑎, 𝑏] into subintervals of equal width, ∆𝑥. Chapter 2 Differential Equations The study of differential equations is among the most important applications of calculus to science and engineering. Differential equations are used to model a wide range of continu- ously changing or evolving process, including: • transfer of heat through an object; • vibrations of a guitar string; • propagation of light, sound, or ocean waves; • movement of celestial bodies; • changing financial markets; • population growth and decay; • spread of infectious disease; • chemical reactions; and many more. The theory of differential equations is vast and comprises an entire branch of mathematics of its own. While we will only scratch the surface of the field here, this chapter serves as an introduction to some of the terminology and techniques that one may explore further in later courses. By the end of this chapter, you will be able to • state key definitions related to the study of differential equations; • recognize and solve simple types of differential equations; • use differential equations to model changes in temperature, population growth, and radioactive decay. 144 Section 2.1 Introduction to Differential Equations 145 2.1 Introduction to Differential Equations First, let us define

Definition 2.1.1 Differential Equation A differential equation (DE), is an equation involving an unknown function and its deriva- tives. The term ordinary differential equation (ODE) refers to a differential equation involv- ing single-variable functions, whereas the termpartial differential equation (PDE) refers to a differential equation involving multivariable functions (i.e., functions with multiple inputs). This chapter will focus solely on ordinary differential equations. Partial differential equa- tions are beyond the scope of our study. An ODE (or simply DE from this point onward) of an unknown function 𝑦 = 𝑦(𝑥) is therefore an equation of the form 𝐹 (︁ 𝑥, 𝑦, 𝑦′, 𝑦′′, . . . , 𝑦(𝑛) )︁ = 0 for some 𝑛 ∈N. Definition 2.1.2 Order of a DE The order of a DE is the order of the highest derivative that appears in the equation. Example 2.1.3 (a) The differential equation 𝑦′= 𝑦 has order 1. It describes all functions 𝑦 that are equal to their own first derivative. (b) The differential equation 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 +𝑦 = 𝑥 also has order 1, since it involves a first derivative but no derivatives of higher orders. (c) The differential equation 𝑥2 𝑑2𝑦 𝑑𝑥2 + 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = 1 has order 2. (d) The differential equation (︀ 𝑦′′′)︀1/3 + 𝑦 (︀ 𝑦′)︀7 −𝑒𝑦′ = 𝑥 has order 3. The equations we will be considering have non-derivative terms that can be separated into a product of the form 𝑔(𝑥)ℎ(𝑦). As such, these DEs are said to be separable. Definition 2.2.1 Separable DE A first-order differential equation is said to be separable if it can be written in the form 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = 𝑔(𝑥)ℎ(𝑦). Example 2.2.2 The differential equation 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = 𝑥 𝑦 is separable, since it can be written as 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = 𝑥 (︂1 𝑦 )︂ = 𝑔(𝑥)ℎ(𝑦). Example 2.2.3 The differential equation 𝑦′= sin(𝑥 + 𝑦) −sin(𝑥) cos(𝑦) may not appear to be separable at first glace, but it turns out it can be recognized as a separable DE after the use of a trigonometric identity. Indeed, we may rewrite the equation as 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = sin(𝑥 + 𝑦) −sin(𝑥) cos(𝑦) = [sin(𝑥) cos(𝑦) + cos(𝑥) sin(𝑦)] −sin(𝑥) cos(𝑦) = cos(𝑥) sin(𝑦). Since the non-derivative terms can be written of the form𝑔(𝑥)ℎ(𝑦), the equation is separable. Example 2.2.4 Both 𝑦′ = 𝑥 + 𝑦 and 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = 𝑒𝑥𝑦 are examples of non-separable DEs. The non-derivative terms cannot be written in the form 𝑔(𝑥)ℎ(𝑦). 2.2.1 Solving a Separable DE Consider a separable differential equation 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = 𝑔(𝑥)ℎ(𝑦). Provided ℎ(𝑦) ̸≡0, we may rewrite the DE as 1 ℎ(𝑦) 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = 𝑔(𝑥). Section 2.2 Separable Differential Equations 153 Since we wish to determine the solution(s) 𝑦, we will attempt to remove the derivative term by integrating both sides of the equation with respect to 𝑥: ∫︁ (︂ 1 ℎ(𝑦) 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 )︂ 𝑑𝑥 = ∫︁ 𝑔(𝑥) 𝑑𝑥. Since 𝑑𝑦 = 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 𝑑𝑥, the integral on the left-hand side can be written simply as ∫︀ 1 ℎ(𝑦) 𝑑𝑦, leading to the integral equation ∫︁ 1 ℎ(𝑦) 𝑑𝑦 = ∫︁ 𝑔(𝑥) 𝑑𝑥. Given specific functions 𝑔(𝑥) and ℎ(𝑦), we will evaluate the integrals on each side of the equation above, leading to an equation with no derivative terms remaining. Provided this equation is not too complicated, we can then isolate for 𝑦 in terms of 𝑥. Observe that the strategy above relies on the assumption that ℎ(𝑦) ̸≡0. In some cases, there may also be solutions where ℎ(𝑦) ≡0, which must be considered separately. We summarize the general strategy as follows. Method Solving a Separable DE Below we present the steps to solve a separable differential equation, 𝑑𝑦 𝑑𝑥 = 𝑔(𝑥)ℎ(𝑦). This method is known as separation of variables. 1. Determine any solutions 𝑦 with ℎ(𝑦) ≡0. 2. Find the solutions 𝑦 where ℎ(𝑦) ̸≡0 by evaluating the integrals ∫︁ 1 ℎ(𝑦) 𝑑𝑦 = ∫︁ 𝑔(𝑥) 𝑑𝑥. If possible, isolate 𝑦 as a function of 𝑥 in the resulting equation. The general solution is the collection of all solutions obtained in Step 1 together with all solutions obtained in Step 2. In this section we will take a detailed look at a few more applications of the DEs we have studied. Specifically, we will explore models for heating and cooling, exponential growth and decay, and logistic population growth. 2.4.1 Newton’s Law of Heating/Cooling Newton’s Law of Heating/Cooling states that the temperature of an object changes at a rate that is proportional to the difference between the temperature of the object and the temperature of its surroundings. We may rephrase Newton’s law as a differential equation. If 𝑇 = 𝑇(𝑡) denotes the temper- ature of the object at time 𝑡 and 𝑇𝑠 denotes the temperature of its surroundings (which is assumed to be constant), then, for some proportionality constant 𝑘 >0, 𝑑𝑇 𝑑𝑡 = −𝑘(𝑇 −𝑇𝑠). REMARKS (i) The constant of proportionality, 𝑘, is a measure of the object’s ability to exchange heat energy and depends on the material properties of the object. (ii) To see why the coefficient of 𝑇 −𝑇𝑠 is negative, observe that if 𝑇 −𝑇𝑠 > 0, then the temperature of the object is greater than that of its surroundings, meaning that 𝑇 should decrease over time (i.e., 𝑑𝑇 𝑑𝑡 < 0). Likewise, if 𝑇 −𝑇𝑠 < 0, then the temperature of the object is lower than that of its surroundings and hence the temperature will increase over time (i.e., 𝑑𝑇 𝑑𝑡 > 0). The negative coefficient ensures that the sign of the derivative is consistent with these expectations. Thus, if 𝑃 = 𝑃(𝑡) denotes the size of a population at time 𝑡, then exponential growth/decay occurs when 𝑑𝑃 𝑑𝑡 = 𝑘𝑃 for some constant 𝑘. Note that if 𝑘 >0, then 𝑑𝑃 𝑑𝑡 > 0, meaning that 𝑃 is increasing (i.e., 𝑃 exhibits growth). If instead 𝑘 <0, then 𝑑𝑃 𝑑𝑡 < 0, meaning that 𝑃 is decreasing (i.e., 𝑃 exhibits decay). The exponential growth DE is both separable and linear and hence can be solved using the methods from sections 2.2 or 2.3. The general solution is 𝑃(𝑡) = 𝐴𝑒𝑘𝑡 for some constant 𝐴. In fact, given an initial population 𝑃(0), we have 𝑃(0) = 𝐴𝑒𝑘(0) = 𝐴. 172 Chapter 2 Differential Equations Theorem 2.4.3 (The Exponential Growth/Decay DE and its Solutions) The solutions to the exponential growth DE 𝑑𝑃 𝑑𝑡 = 𝑘𝑃 are given by 𝑃(𝑡) = 𝐴𝑒𝑘𝑡, where 𝐴 = 𝑃(0). Example 2.4.4 A population of hedgehogs grows exponentially starting with 2 hedgehogs. After 1 year, there are 20 hedgehogs. How many hedgehogs will there be after 100 years? In reality, the availability of food, water, and space, all impose limits on the size a population can reach. The maximum number of organisms that can exist in a population is known as the pop- ulation’s carrying capacity. We will explore a more sophisticated population model that accounts for carrying capacity in the next section. Before moving on, let’s explore an application that is modelled realistically by the expo- nential DE: radioactive decay! Example 2.4.5 Carbon-14 is a radioactive compound that exists in all living organisms. It decays expo- nentially with a half life of around 5730 years, meaning that after this amount of time, half of the atoms in a carbon-14 sample will have decayed. An organism’s carbon-14 supply is constantly renewed while the organism is living, but no new carbon-14 is created after its death. Scientists can therefore use the amount of carbon- Section 2.4 Applications of Differential Equations 173 14 present in a deceased organism to estimate the amount time since its death. This process is known as carbon dating. Given that an animal bone contains 20% of a normal supply of carbon-14, approximately how old is the bone? At 𝑡 = 0, the bone contains 𝑃(0) = 100 percent of its carbon-14 content; and since 𝑃(𝑡) exhibits exponential decay, it follows that 𝑃(𝑡) = 100𝑒𝑘𝑡 for some constant 𝑘. Since carbon-14 has a half-life of 5730 years, 𝑃(5730) = 50 percent. We may use this condition to solve for 𝑘: 𝑃(5730) = 50 = ⇒ 50 = 100𝑒𝑘(5730) =⇒ 𝑒5730𝑘 = 50 100 = 1 2 =⇒ 𝑘 = 1 5730 ln (︂1 2 )︂ Therefore, we find that 𝑃(𝑡) = 100𝑒 𝑡 5730 ln(1/2) = 100 (︁ 𝑒ln(1/2) )︁𝑡/5730 = 100 (︂1 2 )︂𝑡/5730 . We now wish to determine the value of 𝑡 such that 𝑃(𝑡) = 20 percent. We have 𝑃(𝑡) = 20 = ⇒ 100 (︂1 2 )︂𝑡/5730 = 20 =⇒ (︂1 2 )︂𝑡/5730 = 1 5 =⇒ 𝑡 5730 = log1 2 (︂1 5 )︂ =⇒ 𝑡 = 5730 log1 2 (︂1 5 )︂ ≈13304.65. REMARK There are various interesting features of the logistic model that can be observed from this differential equation. Each of these features is consistent with what one would actually observe in populations in nature, thus supporting the accuracy of the logistic model. (i) First consider the case in which the that the population, 𝑃, is well below the carrying capacity, 𝑀. In this case, 𝑃 𝑀 will be approximately 0, hence 𝑑𝑃 𝑑𝑡 = 𝑘𝑃 (︂ 1 −𝑃 𝑀 )︂ ≈𝑘𝑃. Thus, the logistic model predicts exponential growth when the size of the population is well below capacity. (ii) Now consider the case in which the population is near capacity, so 𝑃 is approximately equal to 𝑀. Since 𝑃 𝑀 is then approximately 1, we have 𝑑𝑃 𝑑𝑡 = 𝑘𝑃 (︂ 1 −𝑃 𝑀 )︂ ≈0. That is, the logistic model predicts little to no growth when the population is close to capacity. Chapter 3 Numerical Series In this chapter we will be looking at some ways in which we can sum infinitely many real numbers together. We all have had lots of experiences with such infinite sums already. One of your earliest encounters with the notion of infinity was when you learned that 1 3 = 0.333 . . .= 0.3 + 0.03 + 0.003 + ··· = 3 10 + 3 100 + 3 1000 + ··· . This infinite sum is a special case of the sum of a geometric series (see Example 3.1.12(i) below). It is also clear that there are many infinite sums that cannot be equal to any real number, for example, 1 + 2 + 3 +··· , which is bigger than any fixed real number and should be equal to ∞(see Example 3.1.6 below).

Definition 3.1.10 Geometric Series Let 𝑎, 𝑥∈R such that 𝑎 ̸= 0. We have chosen the convention that for a geometric series, the index 𝑛 starts at 𝑛 = 0 instead of the usual 𝑛 = 1. We define the 𝑚-th partial sum of the geometric series to be 𝑆𝑚 = 𝑚∑︁ 𝑛=0 𝑎𝑥𝑛 = 𝑎 + 𝑎𝑥 + 𝑎𝑥2 + ··· + 𝑎𝑥𝑚. Note that 𝑆𝑚 for a geometric series contains 𝑚 + 1 terms instead of the usual 𝑚 terms. Theorem 3.2.3 (Tail Convergence Theorem) Let {𝑎𝑛}∞ 𝑛=1 be a sequence and let 𝑗 denote a positive integer. (i) If ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 converges, then its tail ∞∑︁ 𝑛=𝑗 𝑎𝑛 also converges for each 𝑗 ≥1. (ii) If the tail ∞∑︁ 𝑛=𝑗 𝑎𝑛 converges for some 𝑗, then ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 also converges. Proof: Let 𝑚 be any positive integer satisfying 𝑚 ≥𝑗. Let 𝑆𝑚 = 𝑚∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 denote the 𝑚-th partial sum of ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛. As we mentioned in the previous section, it is generally quite difficult to compute the sum of a convergent infinite series explicitly. For example, it is known that ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 1 𝑛2 converges to 𝜋2 6 , but the computation is highly non-trivial and requires more advanced calculus than what is covered in this course. However, it is often easier to determine whether a series converges (or diverges) without worrying about what the sum will be. For the rest of this section, we will content ourselves with obtaining a method to quickly determine whether an infinite series diverges. We start with a necessary condition for an infinite series to converge. Theorem 3.2.5 (Necessary Condition for Convergence) If ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 converges, then lim 𝑛→∞ 𝑎𝑛 = 0. Proof: Let 𝑆𝑚 = 𝑚∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 denote the 𝑚-th partial sum of ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛. Suppose that ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 converges, i.e., ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 = lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑆𝑚 = 𝑆 for some 𝑆 ∈ R. We note that 𝑆𝑚 −𝑆𝑚−1 = (𝑎1 + ··· + 𝑎𝑚−1 + 𝑎𝑚) −(𝑎1 + ··· + 𝑎𝑚−1) = 𝑎𝑚 for all 𝑚 ≥2. Hence we conclude that lim 𝑛→∞ 𝑎𝑛 = lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑎𝑚 = lim 𝑚→∞ (𝑆𝑚 −𝑆𝑚−1) = (︁ lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑆𝑚 )︁ − (︁ lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑆𝑚−1 )︁ = 𝑆 −𝑆 = 0. 192 Chapter 3 Numerical Series REMARK Note that we have 𝑚 → ∞if and only if 𝑚 −1 → ∞. Hence we can conclude that lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑆𝑚−1 = lim 𝑚−1→∞ 𝑆𝑚−1 = 𝑆 in the previous proof. The contrapositive statement of the previous theorem is quite useful and has a name. The following theorem is due to a French mathematician Augustin-Louis Cauchy (1789–1857). Section 3.4 Comparison Test and Limit Comparison Test 205 3.4 Comparison Test and Limit Comparison Test In this section, we present two more convergence tests that we can apply to eventually positive series. Theorem 3.4.1 (Comparison Test) Let 𝑘 be a positive integer. Suppose that {𝑎𝑛}∞ 𝑛=1 and {𝑏𝑛}∞ 𝑛=1 are two sequences satisfying 0 ≤𝑎𝑛 ≤𝑏𝑛 for every 𝑛 ≥𝑘. (i) If ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑏𝑛 converges, then ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 converges too. (ii) If ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 diverges, then ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑏𝑛 diverges too. Proof: We first note that (i) and (ii) are contrapositives of one another. Thus it is enough to prove one of them. Let us prove (ii). Suppose that ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 diverges. By part (ii) of the Tail Divergence Theorem (Corollary 3.2.4), we can conlude that its tail ∞∑︁ 𝑛=𝑘 𝑎𝑛 diverges too. Now we note that this tail ∞∑︁ 𝑛=𝑘 𝑎𝑛 is a positive series. By Lemma 3.3.2, this tail ∞∑︁ 𝑛=𝑘 𝑎𝑛 must diverge to ∞. Let 𝑇𝑚 = 𝑚∑︁ 𝑛=𝑘 𝑎𝑛 denote the 𝑚-th partial sum of this tail ∞∑︁ 𝑛=𝑘 𝑎𝑛, where 𝑚 ≥𝑘. Then we have lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑇𝑚 = ∞. Next consider the corresponding tail ∞∑︁ 𝑛=𝑘 𝑏𝑛 and its 𝑚-th partial sum 𝑈𝑚 = 𝑚∑︁ 𝑛=𝑘 𝑏𝑛, where 𝑚 ≥𝑘. Since 𝑎𝑛 ≤𝑏𝑛 for every 𝑛 ≥𝑘 by our hypothesis, we must have 𝑇𝑚 ≤𝑈𝑚 for every 𝑚 ≥𝑘. By taking limits of both sides of the last inequality as 𝑚 →∞, we conclude that ∞= lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑇𝑚 ≤ lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑈𝑚. Thus we must have ∞∑︁ 𝑛=𝑘 𝑏𝑛 = lim𝑚→∞𝑈𝑚 = ∞. Definition 3.5.1 Alternating Series Let {𝑎𝑛}∞ 𝑛=1 be a strictly positive sequence, i.e., 𝑎𝑛 > 0 for each integer 𝑛 ≥ 1. Then 𝑇𝑚 = −𝑆𝑚 and hence lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑇𝑚 = − lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑆𝑚. It follows that lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑆𝑚 exists if and only if lim 𝑚→∞ 𝑇𝑚 exists. Section 3.5 Alternating Series Test 211 Our main theorem in this section is the following convergence test for alternating series, which is due to the German mathematician Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646–1716). Theorem 3.5.4 (Alternating Series Test) Let {𝑎𝑛}∞ 𝑛=1 be a sequence satisfying the following two conditions. (i) lim 𝑛→∞ 𝑎𝑛 = 0. (ii) There is a positive integer 𝑘 such that 𝑎𝑛 ≥𝑎𝑛+1 > 0 for every 𝑛 ≥ 𝑘. In other words, {𝑎𝑛}∞ 𝑛=1 is eventually decreasing (or eventually non-increasing) and eventually strictly positive. Then ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 (−1)𝑛−1𝑎𝑛 and ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 (−1)𝑛𝑎𝑛 both converge. Proof: Without loss of generality, let us assume that 𝑘 = 1. In particular, this means that every 𝑎𝑛 will be positive. By the previous lemma, it is enough to prove that ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 (−1)𝑛−1𝑎𝑛 converges. Let 𝑆𝑚 = 𝑚∑︁ 𝑛=1 (−1)𝑛−1𝑎𝑛 denote the 𝑚-th partial sum of the alternating series ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 (−1)𝑛−1𝑎𝑛. Consider the sequence of even-indexed partial sums: {𝑆2𝑗}∞ 𝑗=1 = {𝑆2, 𝑆4, 𝑆6, 𝑆8, . . .}. For every integer𝑗 ≥1, we have 𝑎2𝑗+1 ≥𝑎2𝑗+2 by our hypothesis (ii) (since we are assuming that 𝑘 = 1). It follows that 𝑆2(𝑗+1) −𝑆2𝑗 = (−1)2𝑗𝑎2𝑗+1 + (−1)2𝑗+1𝑎2𝑗+2 = 𝑎2𝑗+1 −𝑎2𝑗+2 ≥0 for every integer 𝑗 ≥1. Hence {𝑆2𝑗}∞ 𝑗=1 is an increasing (or non-decreasing) sequence. For every integer 𝑗 ≥1, we can write 𝑆2𝑗 = 𝑎1 −(𝑎2 −𝑎3)⏟ ⏞ ≥0 −(𝑎4 −𝑎5)⏟ ⏞ ≥0 −···− (𝑎2𝑗−2 −𝑎2𝑗−1)⏟ ⏞ ≥0 −𝑎2𝑗⏟ ⏞ >0 . Hence 𝑆2𝑗 < 𝑎1 for every integer 𝑗 ≥1, and thus the sequence {𝑆2𝑗}∞ 𝑗=1 is bounded from above.

Section 3.6 Absolute and Conditional Convergence 217 3.6 Absolute and Conditional Convergence So far we have examined convergence tests for eventually positive series and a convergence test for alternating series. In this section, we study a convergence test that can be applied to generic series that have a non-alternating assortment of positive and negative terms. Just like for improper integrals, we will use the absolute values and discuss absolute convergence! We say that the series ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑎𝑛 converges absolutely if its absolutization ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 |𝑎𝑛|converges. The first one is due to a French math- ematician Jean le Rond d’Alembert (1717–1783), and only applies to eventually nonzero series. Theorem 3.7.1 (Ratio Test) Let 𝑘 be a positive integer. Similarly, since there is a strictly positive distance between 𝐿 and 𝑥, we can choose a strictly positive real number 𝜖 >0 such that 𝐿 < 𝐿+ 𝜖 < 𝑥. For what values of 𝑥 >0 does the series, ∞∑︁ 𝑛=1 𝑥𝑛 𝑛𝑥 converge? Chapter 4 Power Series In the previous chapter, we studied the convergence of infinite sums of real numbers. In this chapter, we will be studying the convergence of infinite sums of functions rather than numbers. More precisely, we will be looking at the convergence of “power series”, which is a function that is equal to an infinite sum of power functions of the form: 𝑐𝑛(𝑥 −𝑎)𝑛 (𝑛 = 0, 1, 2, . . .), where 𝑥 is a variable and 𝑐𝑛, 𝑎 are constants. Given any power series, its partial sums are finite sums of power functions, and hence polynomials. Therefore we can estimate the values of a convergent power series by evaluating its partial sums which are polynomials. Since the values of polynomials can always be computed in a relatively simple manner (their computations only involve the addition, subtraction and multiplication of real numbers), we can easily estimate the values of a convergent power series. By the end of this chapter, you will have seen that most differentiable functions that you have encountered in your study of calculus thus far are equal to some power series! More- over, you will have learned how to use power series and their partial sums to compute or estimate those basic functions and their limits and integrals. Indeed, your calculators and computer programs employ the same type of power series methods in the background to obtain estimates for the values of “transcendental” functions like the trigonometric, inverse- trigonometric, exponential and logarithmic functions. 4.1 Introduction to Power Series Definition 4.1.1 Power Series A power series centred at 𝑥 = 𝑎 is an infinite series of the form: ∞∑︁ 𝑛=0 𝑐𝑛(𝑥 −𝑎)𝑛 = 𝑐0

Section 4.8 Big-O Notation 281 4.8 Big-O Notation In this last section, we introduce a notation that is widely used in many fields. Definition 4.8.1 Big-O Notation Let 𝑎 denote a real number or ∞. Assume that 𝑓(𝑥) and 𝑔(𝑥) are two functions that are defined for all real 𝑥 values that are near 𝑎 but are not necessarily defined when 𝑥 = 𝑎. More precisely, if 𝑎 ∈R, we assume that 𝑓(𝑥) and 𝑔(𝑥) are both defined for all 𝑥 in the union 𝐼 = (𝑎 −𝛿, 𝑎) ∪(𝑎, 𝑎+ 𝛿) = {𝑥 ∈R |0 < |𝑥 −𝑎|< 𝛿}, where 𝛿 is some strictly positive real number. If 𝑎 = ∞, we assume that 𝑓(𝑥) and 𝑔(𝑥) are both defined for all 𝑥 in some open interval 𝐼 = (𝑐, ∞), where 𝑐 ∈R. We write 𝑓(𝑥) = 𝑂(𝑔(𝑥)) as 𝑥 →𝑎 (4.25) if there exists a real constant 𝑀 >0 such that |𝑓(𝑥)|≤ 𝑀|𝑔(𝑥)| (4.26) for every 𝑥 ∈𝐼. REMARK Equation (4.25) is read as “𝑓(𝑥) is big-O of 𝑔(𝑥) as 𝑥 goes to 𝑎”.
